whatIsPetCt.title: What is PET-CT?
whatIsPetCt.description: PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography - Computed Tomography) is an advanced medical imaging method that visualizes the metabolic activity of cells in the body. By combining PET and CT technologies, it provides both anatomical and functional information.
bullets: Visualizes metabolic activity at the cellular level
Combines PET and CT technologies in a single scan
Can scan the entire body in one session
Can detect diseases at early stages
Gold standard for evaluating treatment response

steps.title: Radiopharmaceutical Injection
steps.description: A radioactive substance called FDG (fluorodeoxyglucose) is injected intravenously.

steps.title: Waiting Period
steps.description: You rest in a quiet room for approximately 45-60 minutes while the substance distributes throughout the body.

steps.title: Imaging
steps.description: A painless scan lasting approximately 20-30 minutes is performed in the PET-CT machine.

steps.title: Results & Reporting
steps.description: Images are evaluated by expert nuclear medicine physicians and a report is prepared.

items.title: Pregnant Women
items.description: PET-CT is not recommended during pregnancy due to radiation exposure. Be sure to inform your doctor if you are or might be pregnant.

items.title: Breastfeeding Mothers
items.description: If PET-CT is performed during breastfeeding, nursing must be paused for a specific period after the injection.

items.title: Uncontrolled Diabetes Patients
items.description: Image quality may decrease in patients with high blood sugar levels. Blood sugar must be under control before the procedure.

items.title: Severe Kidney Failure
items.description: Special evaluation is required for the contrast CT component in patients with serious kidney dysfunction.

items.title: 6-Hour Fast
items.description: Stop eating and drinking at least 6 hours before the procedure. Water is allowed.

items.title: Blood Sugar Check
items.description: If you have diabetes, your blood sugar must be below 200 mg/dL.

items.title: Avoid Heavy Exercise
items.description: Avoid intense physical activity 24 hours before the procedure.

items.title: Wear Comfortable Clothing
items.description: Choose comfortable, warm clothing without metal accessories.

items.title: Report Your Medications
items.description: Inform your doctor about all medications and supplements you are taking.

items.title: Bring Previous Tests
items.description: Have your previous imaging and laboratory results with you.

items.question: Is PET-CT harmful?
items.answer: The radiation dose used in PET-CT is low and is eliminated from the body quickly. When medically necessary, the benefits far outweigh the potential risks.

items.question: Is PET-CT a painful procedure?
items.answer: No, PET-CT is completely painless. You may only feel a slight prick during the intravenous injection.

items.question: When will PET-CT results be ready?
items.answer: Results are typically ready within 1-2 business days. After our specialist physicians evaluate the images in detail, your report is sent to your referring doctor.

items.question: Do I need to undress for PET-CT?
items.answer: You can enter the procedure in comfortable clothing without metal. If necessary, a special patient gown will be provided.

items.question: Can children have PET-CT?
items.answer: Yes, PET-CT can be performed on children when medically necessary. The dose is adjusted according to the child's weight.

items.question: Do I need a referral for PET-CT?
items.answer: Yes, a doctor's referral is required for PET-CT scanning. You can get a referral from departments such as oncology, neurology, or cardiology.

items.question: How much does PET-CT cost?
items.answer: PET-CT costs may vary depending on the radiopharmaceutical used and additional procedures. Please contact our center for current pricing and insurance coverage information.
